The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Secretary of State for the Colonies (CP.-5 (31))stating that, after consultation with the ForeignOffice and the Governor of Malta, he had reached theconclusion that the wisest course would be to appoint a Royal Commission or Inquiry, and asking the sanction of the Cabinet to take action accordingly. He pro-posed that the Royal Commission should include are tired member of the Diplomatic Service, a ColonialGovernor or other distinguished Official on theretired list, and a person of standing in legalcircles in this country, one of these members being a Roman Catholic. As regards the terms of referencehe considered it sufficient to instruct the Commis-sion to report on "%at steps should be taken to re-establish constitutional government in Malta".The Prime Minister said that he had been inconsultation with the Permanent Secretary to theForeign Office on this subject, and he understoodthat that Department were contemplating some action. He thought the Cabinet ought not to dealwith the question in the absence of the Secretaryof State for Foreign Affairs without knowing theview of the Foreign Office. ., ....In the course of the discussion it was suggestedthat, as delicate political considerations were involved, it might be advisable to entrust the investigation to some independent person ratherthan to a Royal Commission. It was also suggestedthat the announcement of a Royal Commission mighttend to weaken the position vis-a-vis the Vatican.The Cabinet- agreed - (a) That the question should be adjourned for a week, when it was hoped that the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs would be present:That in the meanwhile theSecretary of State for theColonies should keep intouch with the Foreign Offi TIN restriction- 3. The Cabinet had before them a Note (CP.-1(31)) prepared by the Secretariat to the Panel ofMinisters on Unemployment, covering Memoranda bythe Minister of Health, the Minister of Labour andthe President of the Board of Trade, on the problemsof the depressed unemployment areas . This Note was circulated by instructions of the Prime Minister.The Cabinet also had under consideration a Noteby. the President of the Board of Trade (CP.-15 (31))which he was circulating to the Panel of ministers on Unemployment, in continuation of his Note(included in C .P..-1 (31)) on Industrial development in Depressed Areas.A general discussion took place on the subjectof Unemployment Policy, which was in effect a con-continuation of the discussion at the Cabinet on theprevious evening.The Prime Minister reported that he had summoneda meeting of the Panel of Ministers on unemployment to take.place at noon on"the following day, andthat he had also arranged a meeting of the economic advisory Council early next month.There was general agreement that it would be a mistake for the Government to pretend that it waspossible, by means of relief works, and so forth,to make much impression oP- the unemployment figures at the rate at which they are mounting up in conse-quenee of the world depression now prevailing.The present crisis was probably due to the faultysystem under which the whole w-orld was working,,and no Government could be expected, to bring any marked alleviation within 12 or 18 months. The Government'spokesmen.in Debate should make itclear that the unemployed would be kept fromstarvation, and that in the meanwhile theconstructive work of the Government towards thepermanent reduction of unemployment was continuing.It was felt that the point on which it wasnecessary to concentrate was the speeding up of approved schernes .The President of the Board of Trade informed his colleagues that a scheme had been prepared by certain individuals for the re-organisation ofthe whole Iron and Steel Industry on the lines indicated in the Report of the Sub-Oommittee ofthe Economic Advisory Council (CP.-189 (30)).He hoped to receive a copy of this scheme in thenear future, with permission to circulate it tothe Cabinet, fie warned the Cabinet that the ques-tion might arise as to obtaining powers to compel -some small proportion of the industry, that mightstand out, to enter this scheme.It was suggested that one matter that deservedlooking into was the effect on industry of inter-national agreements and cartels allocating marketsor re /nil a t ing f r e i gh t ch ar ge s , and so f orth .Comment was made on the very serious effect onthe unemployment figures of the present restriction of emigration to the Dominions, which, it was stated, might add 200,000 a year to the unemployed in this country.Attention was also drawn to the large unsatis-fied demand in domestic service, and the minister-c Labour stated that the numbers of personsavailable for this form of employment was being increased every week. A Memorandum by the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries, (paper No. CP. 16 (^1)), on thesubject of the position of agricultural labourersin relation to unemployed small holdings, whichhad been reached during the consideration by a parliamentary Committee of the Agricultural Land(Utilisation) Bill, was handed round at the outset of the meeting. In this Memorandum, theMinister of Agriculture and Fisheries stated thatthe Liberals had put down a clause empowering theMinister to provide a small holdina for an agricultural worker even if he is unemployed.Notwithstanding the decision of the Cabinet(referred to in the margin; to the contrary, theMinister of Agriculture and Fisheries, afterconsultation with all available colleagues,had felt himself unable to prevent the adoptionof the clause, for Parliamentary reasons whichwere explained in the Memorandum. Inconsultation with the Chancellor of the Exchequerhe had come to the conclusion that the only practical course open was to leave the clause asit stands, and to announce on the Third reading of the Bill that the Government proposed to acceptthe clause unaltered, bu'G to add a statement as to the realities of the situation with regardto tne physical and other difficulties in providing large numbers of small holdings quickly,so as to avoid raising false hopes.The Cabinet approved the actionof the Minister of Agricultureand Fisheries in Committee, and endorsed the attitude he proposed to take.
